title: Required parameters
content: You will need to provide: a valid workflow id that has been created via Trace.a secret that will be used to authenticate via Account The authentication secret can be one of the following: a CredentialSecret object containing the email and password of the accounta PrivateKeySecret object containing the signing private key of the account Notes: You can find the workflow id in the url of your workflow. For example, when looking at https://trace.stratumn.com/workflow/95572258, the id is 95572258.When a PrivateKeySecret is provided, a unique message is generated, signed and sent to Account for validation. We check that the signature and the message are valid and return an authentication token in that case.

title: Bot set up
content:
In order to use the SDK, you will have to create a bot in the ui. This bot will be linked to one team of your organisation in order to perform actions. You can create one bot in the organisation's configuration page : https://account.stratumn.com/organization/bots. Don't forget to add the bot to the team he should belong in the configuration page : https://account.preprod.stratumn.com/organization/groups. You will need to generate ED25519 ssh keys, and fill the private key in the following format (with the new line at the end): -----BEGIN ED25519 PUBLIC KEY----- Y9Vzvg4Sl7nkI17O6/zbq60w4UP2bv+rI6pJvBy/mo8= -----END ED25519 PUBLIC KEY----- Copy In the SDK's code, you then have to set the private key, replacing line breaks with "
", for example : key = "-----BEGIN ED25519 PRIVATE KEY-----
MmEqkCAUEczwwYB2gGyRg27du9biQmHbOx++XWGimw9j1XO+DdKXueQjX07r/NurrTDhQ/Zu/6sjqkm8HL+ajw==
-----END ED25519 PRIVATE KEY-----
" Copy

title: SDKs configuration
content: JavaScriptC#Java You must start by importing the `Sdk` class definition: var { Sdk } = require("@stratumn/sdk"); Copy You can then create a new instance of the Sdk: var sdk = new Sdk({ workflowId: YOUR_CONFIG.workflowId, secret: { privateKey: YOUR_SECRETS.privateKey }, }); Copy By default the Sdk is configured to point to the production environment of Trace. During a development phase, you can configure the Sdk to point to the staging environment: var sdk = new Sdk({ workflowId: YOUR_CONFIG.workflowId, secret: { privateKey: YOUR_SECRETS.privateKey }, endpoints: { trace: "https://trace-api.staging.stratumn.com", account: "https://account-api.staging.stratumn.com", media: "https://media-api.staging.stratumn.com", }, }); Copy

title: Requesting the transfer of ownership of a trace
content: You can "push" the trace to another group in the workflow this way: JavaScriptC#Java await sdk.pushTrace({ prevLink, // or traceId recipient: YOUR_CONFIG.otherGroup, data: { why: "because", }, }); Copy The arguments are: recipient: the id of the group to push the trace to,data: (optional) some data related to the push transfer,prevLink or traceId. You can also "pull" an existing trace from another group: JavaScriptC#Java await sdk.pullTrace({ prevLink, // or traceId data: { why: "because", }, }); Copy And in this case, the arguments are: data: (optional) some data related to the pull transfer,prevLink or traceId. The Sdk will return the new state object of the trace. The shape of this object is the same as explained previously. Notes: In both cases, the trace is not transferred automatically to or from the group. The recipient must respond to your request as we will see in the next section.You don't need to provide a recipient in the case of a pullTransfer since the two parties of the transfer can be inferred (you and the current owner of the trace).The data object argument is optional. When it is provided, it is a free form object that will not be validated against a JSON schema.

title: Responding to a transfer of ownership of a trace
content: When someone pushed a trace to your group, you can either accept or reject the transfer: JavaScriptC#Java await sdk.acceptTransfer({ prevLink, // or traceId }); Copy Or: await sdk.rejectTransfer({ prevLink, // or traceId data: { reason: "no way!", }, }); Copy Alternatively, if you have initiated the transfer (push or pull), you can also before it has been accepted: await sdk.cancelTransfer({ prevLink, // or traceId }); Copy In all cases, the arguments are: data: (optional) some data related to the pull transfer,prevLink or traceId. The Sdk will return the new state object of the trace. The shape of this object is the same as explained previously. Notes: The data object argument is optional. When it is provided, it is a free form object that will not be validated against a JSON schema.

title: Trace stages
content: Your group in the workflow is composed of multiple stages. There are always 3 default stages: Incoming: this stage lists all the traces that are being transferred to your group (push or pull),Backlog: this stage lists all the traces that have been transferred to your group and accepted,Outgoing: this stage lists all the traces that are being transferred to another group (push or pull). The other stages are called Attestation stages. They compose the logic of your group in the context of this workflow. Notes: When someone pushes a trace to your group, it will appear in your Incoming stage and their Outgoing stage.When you accept a transfer, the trace will move to your Backlog stage.When you reject a transfer, the trace will move back to its previous Attestation stage and disappear from the Outgoing and Incoming stages it was in.

title: üì° Installing
content: JavaScriptC#Java In Node.js The preferred way to install the Stratumn SDK for Node.js is to use theyarn package manager for Node.js. Simply type the following into a terminal window: yarn add @stratumn/sdk Copy

title: üíæ Handling files
content: When providing a data object in an action (via newTrace, appendLink etc.), you can embed files that will automatically be uploaded and encrypted for you. We provide two ways for embedding files, depending on the platform your app is running. JavaScriptC#Java In NodeJs, here is how you would do it: var { FileWrapper } = require("@stratumn/sdk"); var state = await sdk.appendLink({ prevLink, actionKey, data: { operation: "XYZ shipment departed port for ABC", destination: "ABC", customsCheck: true, customsCertificates: [ FileWrapper.fromNodeJsFilePath("/docs/certif_abc.pdf"), FileWrapper.fromNodeJsFilePath("/docs/pic_ea15qw.png"), ], eta: "2019-07-02T12:00:00.000Z", }, }); Copy In the browser, assuming you are working with File objects, you can use: var { FileWrapper } = require("@stratumn/sdk"); var state = await sdk.appendLink({ prevLink, actionKey, data: { operation: "XYZ shipment departed port for ABC", destination: "ABC", customsCheck: true, customsCertificates: [ FileWrapper.fromBrowserFile(certifFile), FileWrapper.fromBrowserFile(pictureFile), ], eta: "2019-07-02T12:00:00.000Z", }, }); Copy Under the hood, all the files are encrypted and uploaded first and the FileWrapper objects found in the data object are converted to a FileRecord object, that will look like this: { mimetype: 'image/png', digest: '1114c7455d6365dc5431c0a1c1388088b793fd8bdec7', key: 'x/Qr55ABlruIU0E4FoE4iCP0tr4Y1EjCt6bb5iCaugs=', name: 'pic_ea15qw.png', size: 235899 } Copy This record uniquely identifies the corresponding file in our service and is easily serializable. If you look in the headLink of the returned state, you will see that the FileWrapper have been converted to FileRecord types: var data = state.headLink.formData(); console.log(data.customCertificates); // will output: // [{ // mimetype: 'application/pdf', // digest: '1114a1ec84cee50603eb285f2006c3b42279fd272d87', // key: 'flBg5AAQI/MBGZnXGYEfuwCEexgkCrD1sXPCYqWvjyc=', // name: 'certif_abc.pdf', // size: 86726 // }, // { // mimetype: 'image/png', // digest: '1114c7455d6365dc5431c0a1c1388088b793fd8bdec7', // key: 'x/Qr55ABlruIU0E4FoE4iCP0tr4Y1EjCt6bb5iCaugs=', // name: 'pic_ea15qw.png', // size: 235899 // } // ] Copy When you retrieve traces with the Sdk, it will not automatically download the files for you. You have to explicitely call a method on the Sdk for that purpose: var state = sdk.getTraceState({ traceId: thePreviousTraceId, }); var dataWithRecords = state.headLink.formData(); var dataWithFiles = sdk.downloadFilesInObject(dataWithRecords); var [certif, pic] = dataWithFiles.customCertificates; consume(certif.decryptedData()); consume(pic.decryptedData()); Copy In this case, certif and pic are FileWrapper objects from which you can extract the raw decrypted data (type Buffer).

title: Creating a new trace
content: You can create a new trace this way: JavaScriptC#Java let myFirstTrace = await sdk.newTrace({ actionKey: YOUR_CONFIG.actionNewShipment, data: { operation: "new shipment XYZ for ABC", weight: 123, valid: true, operators: ["Ludovic K.", "Bernard Q."], }, }); Copy Note that the return type of sdk.newTrace is Promise<TraceState> since this operation is asynchronous. You must await for the response in order to effectively use it. You must provide: actionKey: a valid action key that exists in the targeted workflow,data: the data object corresponding to the action being done. The Sdk will return an object corresponding to the "state" of your new trace. This state exposes the following fields: traceId: the id (uuid format) which uniquely identify the newly created trace,headLink: the link that was last appended to the trace,updatedAt: the Date at which the trace was last updated,updatedBy: the id of the user who last updated the trace,data: the aggregated data modelling the state the trace is in. Notes: The data object argument must be valid against the JSON schema of the form you are using, otherwise Trace will throw a validation error.

title: Appending a link to an existing trace
content: Assuming you have access to the head link of the trace you wish to append a link to (in this example it is myFirstTrace.headLink), you can proceed this way: JavaScriptC#Java await sdk.appendLink({ prevLink: myFirstTrace.headLink, actionKey: YOUR_CONFIG.actionDeparture, data: { operation: "XYZ shipment departed port for ABC", destination: "ABC", customsCheck: true, eta: "2019-07-02T12:00:00.000Z", }, }); Copy If you don't have access to the head link, you can also provide the trace id: await sdk.appendLink({ traceId: someTraceId, actionKey: YOUR_CONFIG.actionDeparture, data: { ... } }); Copy You must provide: actionKey: a valid action key that exists in the targeted workflow,data: the data object corresponding to the action being done,prevLink or traceId. The Sdk will return the new state object of the trace. The shape of this object is the same as explained previously. Notes: The data object argument must be valid against the JSON schema of the form you are using, otherwise Trace will throw a validation error.

title: Trace stages
content: Your group in the workflow is composed of multiple stages. There are always 3 default stages: Incoming: this stage lists all the traces that are being transferred to your group (push or pull),Backlog: this stage lists all the traces that have been transferred to your group and accepted,Outgoing: this stage lists all the traces that are being transferred to another group (push or pull). The other stages are called Attestation stages. They compose the logic of your group in the context of this workflow. Notes: When someone pushes a trace to your group, it will appear in your Incoming stage and their Outgoing stage.When you accept a transfer, the trace will move to your Backlog stage.When you reject a transfer, the trace will move back to its previous Attestation stage and disappear from the Outgoing and Incoming stages it was in.

title: Retrieving traces
content: When all you have is the id of a trace, you can get its state by calling: JavaScriptC#Java await sdk.getTraceState({ traceId, }); Copy The argument: traceId: the id of the trace You can also retrieve the links of a given trace this way: await sdk.getTraceDetails({ traceId, first: 5, }); Copy In this case, we are asking for the first 5 links (see pagination). Arguments: traceId: the id of the trace,first: (optional) retrieve the first n elements,after: (optional) retrieve the elements after a certain point,last: (optional) retrieve the last n elements,before: (optional) retrieve the elements before a certain point. For more explanation on how the pagination work, go to the dedication section. The Sdk will return an object with the details about the trace you asked for. This object exposes the following fields: links: the paginated array of links,totalCount: the total number of links in the trace,info: a pagination object (more on this here). To retrieve all the traces of a given stage, you can: JavaScriptC#Java await sdk.getIncomingTraces({ first: 10, }); Copy Or: await sdk.getOutgoingTraces(); Copy Or: await sdk.getBacklogTraces(); Copy Arguments: first: (optional) retrieve the first n elements,after: (optional) retrieve the elements after a certain point,last: (optional) retrieve the last n elements,before: (optional) retrieve the elements before a certain point. For more explanation on how the pagination work, go to the dedication section. The Sdk will return an object with the traces currently in the given stage. This object exposes the following fields: traces: the paginated array of traces (trace states actually),totalCount: the total number of traces in the trace,info: a pagination object (more on this here).

title: Searching for traces
content: Traces can be searched by tag. So in order to search you must first add a tag to a trace. Tags are not unique, so multiple traces can have the same tag. Traces can also have multiple tags. ‚ö†Ô∏è All traces containing any one of the provided tags will be returned. The tag trace arguments look like: traceId: the id of the trace to add tags tootags: array of tags to add to the trace JavaScriptC#Java await sdk.addTagsToTrace({ traceId: "191516ec-5f8c-4757-9061-8c7ab06cf0a0", tags: ["accepted", "todo"], }); // Now that there is a trace with a tag we can search for it. // In order to search for any of the tags provided, use the `overlaps` parameter : await sdk.searchTraces( { tags: { overlaps: ["todo", "other tag"], }, }, { first: 1, } ); // If you want to search for all tags provided, use the `contains` parameter : await sdk.searchTraces( { tags: { contains: ["todo", "accepted"], }, }, { first: 1, } ); Copy Arguments: filter: specify an array of tags to filter on. All traces containing any one of the provided tags will be returned.paginationInfo: pagination arguments, in case there are multiple traces with the provided tags. More info at pagination

title: Pagination
content: When a method returns an array of elements (traces, links, etc..), it will be paginated. It means that you can provide arguments to specify how many elements to retrieve from which point in the full list. The pagination arguments will always look like: first: (optional) retrieve the first n elements,after: (optional) retrieve the elements after a certain point,last: (optional) retrieve the last n elements,before: (optional) retrieve the elements before a certain point. You must use first and/or after together, last and/or before together. If you try to retrieve the first=n before=xyz the Sdk will throw an error. In the result object, you will have the totalCount and an info object that has the following fields: hasNext: a flag telling if there is a next series of elements to retrieve after this one,hasPrevious: a flag telling if there is a previous series of elements to retrieve before this one,startCursor: (optional) a cursor (string) representing the position of the first element in this series,endCursor: (optional) a cursor (string) representing the position of the last element in this series. Let's look at a pagination example. We start by retrieving (and consuming) the first 10 incoming traces: JavaScriptC#Java let results = await sdk.getIncomingTraces({ first: 10, }); consume(results.traces); Copy Next, we look at the pagination info results to know if there are more traces to retrieve: if (results.info.hasNext) { results = await sdk.getIncomingTraces({ first: 10, after: results.info.endCursor, }); consume(results.traces); } Copy In the case there are more traces to retrieve (hasNext === true), we call the getIncomingTraces method again setting the after argument to the endCursor. We keep doing this until hasNext === false. Putting all this together, we can synthetize this in a loop: let results; do { results = await sdk.getIncomingTraces({ first: 10, after: results.info.endCursor, }); consume(results.traces); } while (results.info.hasNext); Copy
